annotation.TEXT: Moving right along though, we have the final level of this section: The Power Plant. My best advice for this stage is to get the Elec Armor if you haven't yet (for whatever reason). All the enemies and hazards here, especially the boss, will deal quite a bit of damage (even if you've been going out of your way to get HP Memories).

For reference, this isn't how you're supposed to do this section. The intended way involves going to the right, up and around to get here. If you have enough double jump chips though, you can easily cut out a good amount of otherwise required backtracking.

As far as the boss goes, ElecMan.EXE is one of the more technical battles in the game. Much like Quick Man and Bright Man, he operates on a counter attack system. If you hit him once, he'll teleport near you and try to zap you. While this leaves him vulnerable, actually damaging him also causes him to summon clouds that will eventually rain down lightning bolts. Spacing and timing is very important in this fight, which is why throwing chips aren't really the best idea (they take too long to actually hit him, from my experience).

This teleporter leads to a slot machine mini-game. Winning it can yield a few different prizes (mainly, battle chips). Even though it only costs 500 zenny to play each time, it's still a better idea to save your money. Trust me, there's way more helpful things you can spend it on.

If you find yourself low on zenny and you want to buy some of the new chips that Higsby and NumberMan.EXE eventually get, then this area of the Arcade Comp is probably your best bet for grinding money (at this point in the game, at least). You can easily get thousands of zenny just by casually going through this stage alone, in actuality.

ColorMan.EXE isn't really the most difficult boss in the game, just a bit tricky. Aside from having the most HP out of any boss at this point (700, to be exact), you need to hit the upper part of his body for the hit to register. The ball that makes up his lower half is completely immune to damage.

After deciding it probably wasn't a good idea to try to play the rest of this game while half-asleep, I took a break between recordings and actually went back to fight ColorMan.EXE properly. I think it goes without saying that the rest of the gameplay in this video should see an improvement as well.

And there we go. With Elec Man down, that ends this section of the game. At this point, prepare for a bit of a plot dump before we can actually move on. If anything however, I can at least say with certainty that the rest of the game should prove to be more interesting (especially when it comes to a few specific stages).

^ ColorMan.EXE has absolutely no knowledge of the Zero Virus. Keep this in mind, because it'll be important later (admittedly it's kind of a nitpick, but I can't help but point it out when it becomes relevant).

With all that said and done, welcome to the Arcade Comp. This area is, more or less, your first chance at getting some serious upgrades to your chip folder. Hi-Cannon, Sonic Wave, and Cross Bomb chips can be dropped from their respective enemies here. Additionally, you can get the Heat Spread chip from a lone Buffy virus in this first area. Heat Spread itself is quite useful...if you can somehow farm enough of them this early on.

ColorMan.EXE's Navi chip and ability chip basically do the same thing; They send out a bouncing ball to damage enemies. While fairly strong, the chips do have a problem in that you can potentially miss your enemies completely. If you don't position yourself right, you'll just end up wasting your attack.
^ Lan's gonna need some ice for that burn.

Much like what I did in the first Arcade Comp area, this isn't how you're intended to progress in this section. The general idea is that you're supposed to climb up the left side, then go down the right side if you want to get some extra items. If you have at least 8 Double Jump chips though, you can make your way up the right side and skip backtracking all together.

Believe it or not, I'm more interested in Quick Man's ability chip rather than his Navi chip. They both essentially do the same thing (they fire out boomerangs in an arcing pattern), but the Quick Boomerang chip itself allows you to throw three boomerangs at once. The only thing Quick Man's Navi chip has over it is that it can potentially hit things multiple times (which mostly depends on your placement and the width of the enemy).

For reference, what you saw right there wasn't a double jump usage. In this game, you can actually perform an immediate jump once you exit a slide from a narrow space, even if it doesn't lead to solid ground. The timing for this is very tight, but if you can pull it off here, you'll save yourself a double jump chip (which can help in skipping a portion of the next area).

If the title of this video is any indication, I'll be going through two levels in this segment. As a forewarning however, prepare for some rather lackluster playing in the first half. I guess this could serve as a testament as to why I shouldn't try recording things at 3 in the morning (although the second half was recorded at a more reasonable hour, for reference).
